details.description: You can nominate anyone for honours like BEMs, MBEs, OBEs and knighthoods for outstanding achievements and contributions to public life

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
The honours system recognises people who’ve made great achievements in public life and people who’ve committed themselves to serving Britain. They will usually have made life better for other people or been outstanding at what they do.

People get honours for achievements like:

  • making a difference to their community or field of work
  • enhancing Britain’s reputation
  • long-term voluntary service
  • innovation and entrepreneurship
  • changing things, with an emphasis on achievement
  • improving life for people less able to help themselves
  • displaying moral courage and vision in making and delivering tough choices

Honours are given to people involved in different activities, including:

  • arts and media
  • health
  • education
  • science and technology
  • economy (including business etc)
  • community, voluntary and local services
  • sport
  • state (including civil service, politicians etc)

parts.title: Nominate someone
parts.body:
The person must still be actively involved in the area they’re nominated for.

You can nominate anyone. Which honour someone gets is decided by honours committees and their decisions are passed through the Prime Minister to the Queen, who awards the honour.

Download the ‘Nomination pack’ (English) (PDF, 149KB)

Download the ‘Nomination pack’ (English) (RTF, 3,698KB)

Download the ‘Nomination pack’ (Welsh) (RTF, 1,821KB)

Download ‘Honours: how to write citations’ (PDF, 390KB)

The completed forms or any enquiries should be sent to the Honours and Appointments Secretariat.

Cabinet Office
Honours and Appointments Secretariat
Ground Floor
Room G39
1 Horse Guards Road
London
SW1A 2HQ

honours@cabinet-office.x.gsi.gov.uk
Telephone: 020 7276 2777
Fax: 020 7276 2766

What happens next

The nominee should not expect to hear anything for 12 to 18 months.

Honours committees made up of experts and civil servants compare similar nominations, eg teacher with teacher.

parts.title: Types of honours and awards
parts.body:
You can’t nominate someone for a specific honour - that’s decided by the honours committee.

Types of honours

Companion of Honour

A major contribution to the arts, science, medicine, or government lasting over a long period of time.

Knight/Dame

A major contribution in any activity, usually at national level. Other people working in the nominee’s area will see their contribution as inspirational and significant, requiring commitment over a long period of time.

Commander of the British Empire (CBE)

A prominent but lesser role at national level, or a leading role at regional level. You can also get one for a distinguished, innovative contribution to any area.

Order of the British Empire (OBE)

A major local role in any activity, including people whose work has made them known nationally in their chosen area.

Member of the British Empire (MBE)

A significant achievement or outstanding service to the community. An MBE is also awarded for local ‘hands-on’ service which stands out as an example to other people.

British Empire Medal (BEM)

Reintroduced in 2012, this rewards a sustained, local contribution or innovative, high-impact work of a relatively short duration (eg 3-4 years).

Which order?

The committee decides which order someone should be a member of. You don’t have to specify this in your nomination.

Order Who can be nominated
Order of the Bath Senior civil servants and military officers
Order of St Michael and St George Diplomats and people serving the UK abroad
Order of the British Empire Anyone
Companion of Honour (award) Anyone

Most awards are in the Order of the British Empire.

parts.title: Honours lists
parts.body: The lists of who’s received honours are published in the London Gazette on New Year’s Day and the Queen’s birthday in June.

parts.title: Having honours taken away
parts.body:
Someone’s who’s been given an honour and has done something to bring the honours system into disrepute can have their honour taken away (‘forfeited’). Examples include if someone has been:

  • sentenced to imprisonment of at least 3 months for a criminal offence
  • censured, struck off etc by a relevant professional or regulatory authority for something directly relevant to the granting of the honours (eg a doctor has been struck off)

Other criteria can be considered as well. The Honours Forfeiture Committee’s discussions are confidential.

Forfeiture - what happens

The Honours Forfeiture Committee looks at the evidence and considers the case. If the committee makes a recommendation that an order should be forfeited, it is submitted to the Queen by the Prime Minister. The Queen decides if the honour should be forfeited.

If someone’s honour is forfeited it’s published in the London Gazette.

parts.title: Members of honours committees
parts.body:
Honours committees are made up of senior civil servants (‘official members’) and people who are independent of government (‘independent members’). All honours committees have a majority of members who are independent.

Each honours committee has an independent chairperson. A representative from 10 Downing Street is invited to attend all committee meetings

Honours committees review honours nominations for people involved in specific activities (like arts and media or sport) which are then sent to the main committee.

Main committee

Members are:

  • Head of the Home Civil Service (chair)
  • Chair of Arts and Media Committee: Sir Vernon Ellis
  • Chair of Community, Voluntary and Local Services Committee: TBC
  • Chair of the Economy Committee: Sir John Parker GBE
  • Chair of Education Committee: Sir Michael Barber
  • Chair of Health Committee: Sir Ian Carruthers OBE
  • Chair of Science and Technology Committee: The Lord Krebs
  • Chair of Sport Committee: The Lord Coe of Ranmore KBE
  • Chair of State Committee: Dame Mary Marsh DBE
  • The Cabinet Secretary
  • The Permanent Secretary of the Foreign and Commonwealth Office
  • The Chief of Defence Staff
  • Another Permanent Secretary (currently Sir Paul Jenkins KBE, the Treasury Solicitor)

Arts and Media

Sir Vernon Ellis - Chair, British Council (independent chair)

Independent members:

  • The Lord Fellowes of West Stafford DL - writer, actor and director
  • Dame Liz Forgan DBE - Chair of the Arts Council of England and of the Scott Trust
  • Luke Rittner - Chief executive, Royal Academy of Dance
  • Sir Peter Stothard - Editor, The Times Literary Supplement

Official members:

  • Jonathan Stephens - Permanent Secretary, Department for Culture, Media and Sport
  • Sir Peter Housden KCB - Permanent Secretary, Scottish Government

Community, Voluntary and Local Services

Dame Clare Tickell DBE (independent chair) - Chief Executive, Action for Children

Independent members:

  • Evelyn Asante-Mensah OBE DL - Chair, NHS Manchester
  • Sue Charteris - former Director of Shared Intelligence; member of the England Committee, Big Lottery Fund and former Chief Executive of Merton
  • Dilwar Hussain - Head, Policy Research Centre
  • Dr. Angus Kennedy OBE - Chief Executive, Community Regeneration Partnership
  • John Knight CBE JP - Board Member, Charity Commission
  • Brian O’Doherty - Head of Housing, Newcastle City Council
  • The Lord Shipley - Leader, Newcastle City Council
  • Dame Clare Tickell - Chief Executive, Action for Children
  • Sir Nicholas Young - Chief Executive, British Red Cross

Official members:

  • Sir Bob Kerslake - Permanent Secretary, Department for Communities and Local Government
  • Ursula Brennan - Permanent Secretary, Ministry of Defence
  • Sir Peter Housden KCB - Permanent Secretary, Scottish Government
  • Helen Kirkpatrick CB - Acting Permanent Secretary, Home Office
  • Chris Wormald - Permanent Secretary, Department for Education

The Economy

Sir John Parker (independent chair) - Chair, Anglo American plc

Independent members:

  • Dame Helen Alexander DBE - former President, CBI
  • Dr Colette Bowe - Chair, Office of Communications (Ofcom)
  • The Rt Hon Baroness Dean of Thornton-le-Fylde - Member, House of Lords Appointment Commission
  • Rosemarie Harris - famer and County Councillor, Powys County Council
  • Sir Richard Lambert - former Director General, CBI
  • Sir Rob Margetts CBE - Chairman, Legal and General plc
  • Dr Yvonne Thompson CBE - entrepreneur

Official members:

  • Martin Donnelly CMG - Permanent Secretary, Department for Business, Innovation and Skills
  • Jonathan Stephens - Permanent Secretary, Department for Culture, Media and Sport
  • Sir Nicholas MacPherson KCB - Permanent Secretary, HM Treasury
  • Sir Peter Housden KCB - Permanent Secretary, Scottish Government

Education

Professor Sir Michael Barber - Head, McKinsey’s Global Education Practice (independent chair)

Independent members:

  • Professor the Baroness Afshar OBE - Professor, Politics and Women’s Studies, University of York
  • Graham Badman CBE - former Managing Director,Children, Schools and Education Directorate, Kent County Council
  • Sheila Gupta - Director of Human Resources, University of Edinburgh
  • Professor Sir Deian Hopkin - former Vice Chancellor and Chief Executive, London South Bank University
  • Marion Matchett CBE - Civil Service Commissioner for Northern Ireland
  • Professor Graham Shipley - School of Archaeology and Ancient History, University of Leicester
  • Peter Williams CBE - former Chief Executive, Quality Assurance Agency for Higher Education

Official members:

  • Martin Donnelly CMG - Permanent Secretary, Department for Business, Innovation and Skills
  • Chris Wormald - Permanent Secretary, Department for Education
  • Dr. Malcolm McKibbin - Head, Northern Ireland Civil Service

Health

Sir Ian Carruthers OBE - Chief Executive, South West Strategic Health Authority (independent chair)

Independent members:

  • Dame Christine Beasley DBE - Chief Nursing Officer for England
  • Sir Leszek Borysiewicz FRS - Vice-Chancellor, University of Cambridge
  • Dame Ruth Carnall DBE - Chief Executive, NHS London
  • Professor Sir Ian Gilmore - Chair, Liverpool Health Partners, University of Liverpool
  • Dame Janet Husband DBE - former Chair, Royal College of Radiologists Council
  • Professor The Lord Kakkar - Director, Thrombosis Research Institute
  • Sir Nicholas Partridge OBE - Chief Executive, Terrence Higgins Trust

Official members:

  • Dame Sally Davies DBE - Chief Medical Officer (England)
  • Una O’Brien CB - Permanent Secretary, Department of Health

Parliamentary and Political Service

The Lord Spicer - Member, House of Lords (independent chair)

Independent members:

  • Dianne Bevan - Chief Operating Officer, National Assembly
  • The Rt Hon the Lord Butler of Brockwell KG GCB CVO
  • The Rt Hon the Baroness Hayman GBE
  • Dame Mary Keegan DBE
  • The Rt Hon Peter Riddell CBE

Official members:

  • The Rt Hon Alistair Carmichael MP - Liberal Democrat Chief Whip
  • The Rt Hon Sir George Young Bt MP - Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasury and Chief Whip
  • The Rt Hon Rosie Winterton MP - Labour Chief Whip

Science and Technology

The Lord Krebs FRS - Principal, Jesus College, Oxford (independent chair)

Independent members:

  • Professor Sir Tony Atkinson FBA - Senior Research Fellow, Nuffield College
  • Professor Dame Janet Finch DBE DL - former Vice Chancellor, Keele University
  • Professor Dame Julia King DBE - Vice-Chancellor, Aston University
  • Professor Dame Nancy Rothwell DBE FRS DL - President and Vice Chancellor, University of Manchester

Official members:

  • Professor Sir John Beddington CMG, FRS - Chief Scientific Adviser to HM Government
  • Professor John Perkins CBE - Chief Scientific Adviser, Department for Business, Innovation and Skills

Sport

The Lord Coe of Ranmore KBE - Chairman, London Organising Committee for the 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games (independent chair)

Independent members:

  • Baroness Grey Thompson DBE - former Paralympic athlete
  • Tim Lamb - Chief Executive, Sport and Reaction Alliance
  • Tim Phillips - former Chairman, All England Lawn Tennis Club
  • Graham Taylor OBE - former England Football Manager

Official members:

  • Jonathan Stephens - Permanent Secretary, Department for Culture, Media and Sport
  • Dr. Malcolm McKibbin - Head, Northern Ireland Civil Service

State

Dame Mary Marsh DBE - Director, Clore Social Leadership Programme (independent chair)

Independent members:

  • Dame Suzi Leather DBE DL - former Chair, Charity Commission
  • Elizabeth McKeikan - Non-Executive Director, JD Wetherspoon plc. and former Civil Service Commissioner
  • Dr. Diana Walford CBE - former Principal, Mansfield College, Oxford

Permanent Secretary members:

  • Sir Bob Kerslake - Head of the Home Civil Service
  • Sir Paul Jenkins KCB QC - Chief Executive and Permanent Secretary, Treasury Solicitor’s Department
